title: Boston City Council District 7 race: Miniard Culpepper and Said Ahmed
author: Madison Lucchesi and Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Miniard Culpepper and Said Ahmed are running for the Boston City Council's District 7 seat.
Former Councilor Tania Fernandes Anderson resigned and was sentenced to one month in prison for public corruption.
Said Ahmed emphasizes addressing housing issues and plans to enhance resident engagement with City Hall.

title: Boston City Council District 6 race: Ben Weber and Steven Berry
author: Madison Lucchesi and Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Incumbent Ben Weber is facing a challenge from Steven Berry in Boston City Council District 6 race.
Housing is the primary issue in District 6; Berry advocates for changing zoning laws to increase housing availability.
Berry, highlighting his working-class background, calls for bold action and improved public perception of the City Council.

title: Market Basket shopper says she found a widow spider in grapes
author: Beth Treffeisen
bullets: A New Hampshire shopper found a widow spider in a container of Anthony's Organic red grapes from Market Basket.
Calista Plaisted identified the spider using Google and confirmed it with a University of New Hampshire expert.
Market Basket stated they had sold out of the grapes and would notify the supplier about the incident.

title: Boston City Council District 5 race: Enrique Pepén and Winston Pierre
author: Madison Lucchesi and Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Enrique Pepén, incumbent since 2024, faces challenger Winston Pierre in Boston City Council District 5 election.
Pepén cites affordable housing and street safety as major issues, emphasizing investment in safer streets and cleaner parks.
Pierre focuses on underinvestment, advocating for an Anti-Displacement Relief Fund and District 5 Advisory Council.

title: Boston City Council District 4 race: Brian Worrell and Helen Cameron
author: Madison Lucchesi and Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Incumbent Brian Worrell is challenged by Helen Cameron in the Boston City Council District 4 election on November 4.
Cameron highlights financial struggles, cultural integration, and mass transit issues as priorities for District 4's City Council.
Cameron emphasizes her independence from special interest groups and long-standing ties to the district and public service experience.

title: Boston City Council District 2 race: Ed Flynn and Charles Delaney
author: Madison Lucchesi and Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Ed Flynn, serving since 2017, faces challenger Charles Delaney in Boston City Council District 2 race.
Flynn identifies Mass. & Cass crisis as a major issue, advocating for a treatment-first recovery campus.
Flynn emphasizes rebuilding public trust, citing past ethical issues and proposing an Ethics Committee, which was rejected.

title: Look inside the $65 million renovation of Boston’s oldest hotel
author: Kristi Palma
bullets: Omni Parker House in Boston completed a $65 million renovation for its 170th anniversary.
The renovation included updates to all 551 guest rooms, lobby, Rooftop Ballroom, and 19 meeting rooms.
New 'Legend Suites' honor Boston landmarks, and the lobby features bespoke furnishings and marble flooring.

title: Boston City Council District 1 race: Gabriela Coletta Zapata
author: Madison Lucchesi and Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Gabriela Coletta Zapata has been representing Boston's District 1 on the City Council since 2022.
Key issues in District 1 include high rents and the need for inclusive, equitable, and affordable growth.
Coletta Zapata emphasizes transparency and accountability, hosting events to involve resident feedback in local governance.

title: Boston City Council at-large race: Frank Baker
author: Madison Lucchesi and Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Frank Baker, a former City Councilor with 12 years of experience, is running for an at-large seat on the Boston City Council.
Baker believes that the cost of living is Boston's biggest issue and suggests budget cuts to lower taxes and spending.
He emphasizes his 37 years of experience as a key differentiator from other City Council candidates in the current race.

title: Boston City Council at-large race: Julia Mejia
author: Madison Lucchesi and Ross Cristantiello
bullets: Julia Mejia is seeking re-election for her at-large seat on the Boston City Council, which she's held since 2019.
Mejia emphasizes addressing Boston's housing issues by enhancing tenant protections, rent control, and affordable homeownership opportunities.
She distinguishes herself by refusing political endorsements and prioritizing accountability to residents over political alliances.
